channel.title: Dong - A place to track my time log
channel.description: Recent content on Dong - A place to track my time log

item.title: 21. Microservices
item.description: Microservice is a combination of multiple independent applications.

item.title: 19. Publish to the Production Server
item.description: Publish SpringBoot applications to a production environment server in the form of jar packages.

item.title: 17. Wish List
item.description: We can add our favorite products into wish list.

item.title: 15. New Arrivals - When and Choose in MyBatis
item.description: We can show our newly arrived products on the home page.

item.title: 14. Top Products - Connect to Redis with Jedis
item.description: Redis can be used to cache data that needs to be accessed frequently, data will be cached in memory, and we can manipulate Redis through Jedis.

item.title: 13. Merchant List and Detail
item.description: Merchants can sell their own products on the platform for consumers to buy.

item.title: 12. Product Detail - Product and Merchant Info
item.description: Customers can learn about the product information that a merchant has sold through the product details page.

item.title: 11. Product List - Pagination
item.description: Through paging techniques, we can only show some of the products.

item.title: 10. Static Resources - Nginx Configuration
item.description: With the Nginx server, we can increase the speed of loading static resources.

item.title: 9. User Authentication - Spring Interceptor
item.description: We can use Spring Interceptor feature to authenticate user more efficiently.

item.title: 8. User Login - Spring Security
item.description: Registered users can log into the system through a login interface.

item.title: 7. User Registration - Spring Security
item.description: The user can register an account to carry on the goods purchase operation.

item.title: 6. Modularization and Decoupling - Maven
item.description: Through the maven modularization mechanism, we can separate different types of functions and store them in different modules.

item.title: 5. Template Engine - Apache FreeMarker Macro
item.description: Through the macro features provided by FreeMarker, we can easily manage some of the commonly used template code.

item.title: 4. Template Engine - Apache FreeMarker
item.description: FreeMarker is a java-based template engine, commonly used to generate dynamic mvc architecture web pages.

item.title: 3. Connection Pool - Alibaba Druid and Google Guava
item.description: Druid is a database connection pool component developed by Alibaba middleware team. It includes powerful connection pool monitoring features.

item.title: 2. Database Access - MyBatis and MariaDB 10.x
item.description: We first need to install a MariaDB 10.x database locally, and then access the database through MyBatis configuration.

item.title: 1. HelloWorld Demo - Hello Spring Stack
item.description: Let’s use the spring initializer web features provided by the spring website to generate a super-simple hello world project.

item.title: 82. System Log Management - rsyslogd
item.description: rsyslogd is a system utility that provides support for message logging. Support for network and domain sockets enables this utility to support both local and remote logging.

item.title: 81. Package Management - yum (Yellowdog Updater Modified)
item.description: yum is an interactive package manager based on rpm packages.

item.title: 80. Package Management - rpm (RPM Package Manager)
item.description: rpm is a tool that can be used to find, verify, install, update and delete applications.

item.title: 79. Daemon Management - Systemd and Systemctl
item.description: Through the systemctl command, we can easily manage the systemd system and services.

item.title: 78. Job Scheduling - anacron
item.description: anacron can execute commands or scripts periodically; this tool comes from the cronie package as well.

item.title: 77. Job Scheduling - crontab
item.description: crontab is a tool for configuring scheduled tasks. It also maintains each user’s own crontab files.

item.title: 76. Job Scheduling - at
item.description: Queue, check, or delete a job that needs to be scheduled for execution.

item.title: 74. Process Management - sar
item.description: sar is a tool for collecting, reporting, or storing system activity information.

item.title: 73. Process Management - pmap and pstree
item.description: pmap and pstree can let us view the memory map f the process or show processes as a tree.

item.title: 72. Process Management - nice and renice
item.description: With the nice and renice commands, we can specify the priority of a program when it starts, or change the priority of a running process.

item.title: 71. Process Management - kill and killall
item.description: The kill command can terminate the process by the process ID or name, and the killall command can terminate the process itself and its associated processes by the process name.

item.title: 70. Process Management - iostat
item.description: A tool called iostat can be used to display CPU reports, it can also be used to display disk, partition input and output statistics reports.

item.title: 69. Process Management - glances
item.description: We can monitor system resource usage through the glances tool, which also supports cross-platform monitoring.

item.title: 68. Process Management - dstat
item.description: We can use the dstat tool to generate statistics on system resource usage.

item.title: 67. Process Management - &, bg, fg, jobs and nohup
item.description: With commands such as bg fg jobs, we can do something about jobs in the background.

item.title: 66. Process Management - top and htop
item.description: We can view the dynamic information of all processes through two tools, top and htop, which support interactive viewing of processes.

item.title: 65. Process Management - ps
item.description: We can view snapshot information for the current processes through the ps command.

item.title: 64. Process Management - pgrep, pkill and pidof
item.description: We can view the process through the pgrep command, and we can signal the process through the pkill command.

item.title: 63. LVM - Logical Volume Management
item.description: Through the logical volume management technology provided by Linux, we can flexibly manipulate the file systems in every volume.

item.title: 62. RAID - Redundant Array of Independent Disks
item.description: With RAID technology, we can combine multiple disks in some way to improve performance or reliability.

item.title: 61. Disk Management - Tools
item.description: Linux provides us with a lot of tools to manage disks. These tools allow us to view disk usage and partition the drive.

item.title: 60. Disk Management - Concept
item.description: Data is the most critical thing in the system, and the disk is the necessary hardware device to persist the data.

item.title: 59. Advanced Text Processing - Awk's Basic Usage
item.description: Awk is a flexible pattern matching, text processing and line-oriented language, Linux provides us with an implementation version of it, gawk.

item.title: 58. Advanced Text Processing - Stream Editor (sed)
item.description: We can use the sed stream editor provided by linux to filter and convert text line by line.

item.title: 57. Advanced Text Processing - grep, egrep
item.description: We can use the grep tool provided by linux to find matching rows based on either the basic or extended regular expressions.

item.title: 56. Advanced Text Editor - Vim's Visual and Input Mode
item.description: In addition to the last line mode and edit mode, vim also provides us with two other modes: view mode for copying, pasting, deleting selected content, and insert mode to add and delete text.

item.title: 55. Advanced Text Editor - Vim's Edit Mode
item.description: In addition to last line mode, vim also has edit mode, both of which complement each other.

item.title: 54. Advanced Text Editor - Vim's Last Line Mode
item.description: Through the last line mode of vim, we can easily execute some commands, such as switching between files, saving files, moving the cursor, deleting and replacing text and so on.

item.title: 53. Advanced Text Editor - Vim's Common Usage
item.description: The Vim text editor provides instructions that make it easy for us to operate, through which we can open files in a variety of ways.

item.title: 52. Find Utilities - Advanced Files Searching
item.description: The find command provides some useful options for finding files or directories based on creation time, modification time, owner, group, permissions, type, size, etc.

item.title: 51. File Permissions - File Attributes
item.description: To make our files more secure, Linux provides a feature called file attribute. By configuring the attributes of the file, we can specify whether it is read-only or undeleted, or in other statuses.

item.title: 50. File Permissions - Filesystem Access Control List
item.description: Although the chmod command is powerful enough, it cannot assign permissions more finely, so Linux provides some flexible commands to specify permissions for a particular user or group. Starting from Linux kernel 2.6, we can allocate more granular permissions to users or groups.

item.title: 49. User Management - su, sudo
item.description: We can switch between users through the su and sudo commands. Also, we can use these two commands to perform certain command operations with the privileges of other users.

item.title: 48. User Management - Communications Between Users
item.description: Linux provides users with tools to communicate with each other. Some can send messages to a specified user; some can send a group of messages; some can even send content as an email to a user’s inbox list.

item.title: 47. User Management - Login Details & Record
item.description: Linux provides some commands to view the user: login status, login record, login attempt log, user last login log and so on.

item.title: 46. User Management - Creation, Modification and Deletion
item.description: To make it easier to manage users, linux provides some common commands that allow you to add, delete, and modify users in a more standardized way.

item.title: 45. Group Management - Creation, Modification and Deletion
item.description: To make it easier to manage groups, linux provides some common commands that allow you to add, delete, and modify groups in a more standardized way.

item.title: 44. File Permissions - chown, chgrp, chmod, umask
item.description: In order to make it easier to manage user and group permissions on files and directories, linux provides some common commands that can assign and reclaim permissions to users and groups in a more standardized way.

item.title: 43. File Permissions - Symbolic & Numeric Modes, Setuid & Setgid
item.description: We can determine the permissions of a file by looking at the mode bits of that file.

item.title: 42. User Information - IDs, Group IDs, Names, and so on
item.description: The Linux core toolset provides us with some commands to view user-related information.

item.title: 41. Archiving - Compressing and Decompressing Files
item.description: By compressing files and directories into a compressed file, we can easily move and back up the compressed file.

item.title: 40. Find Utilities - Commands & Files Searching Usages
item.description: There are many things we can do with some combination of find and other commands. We can use some commands on the files we find.

item.title: 39. Find Utilities - Commands & Files Searching Basics
item.description: Linux provides us with tools that make it easy for us to find the location of files and commands quickly and efficiently.

item.title: 38. Processes - Running Jobs Management
item.description: In linux, each running program will create at least one process in memory, and each process will be assigned a process ID, we can use the ID of the process to do the corresponding operation of a running program.

item.title: 37. Text Editor - Basic Usage of Nano
item.description: By using the nano text editor provided by Linux, we can easily do some simple text editing operations such as adding, deleting, modifying, etc.

item.title: 36. System Context - Information
item.description: Linux provides commands that allow you to view system-related information, and with these commands, you can quickly get some necessary system information.

item.title: 35. System Context - Date
item.description: Linux provides commands that allow you to view system’s date information, and with these commands, you can quickly get the date related information.

item.title: 34. System Context - Time
item.description: Linux provides commands that allow you to view system’s time information, and with these commands, you can quickly get the time related information.

item.title: 33. Output Format - Prints Formatted Results
item.description: Linux provides a printf command through which we can format what we want to output.

item.title: 32. Bash Shell - Startup Files
item.description:
Bash’s startup configuration file can help us pre-load some other script files as well as preset general and necessary variables.

Bash provides two types of startup files, one that is loaded on login and the other that is loaded on non-login.

item.title: 31. Bash Shell - Expansions: Command, Arithmetic, Process Substitution
item.description: Linux provides us with some expansions for command, arithmetic, addition and subtraction, comparison, ternary, assignment, and process substitution operations.

item.title: 30. Bash Shell - Expansions: brace, tilde, parameter
item.description: Linux provides us with some expansions for duplicate, print current user’s directory, and parameter operations.

item.title: 29. Bash Shell - Variables Operations
item.description: I believe that people who have learned how to program know what variables are, and at first it can be understood as an alias that points to the data stored in memory.

item.title: 28. Bash Shell - Most Commonly Used Control Operators
item.description: We can use the control operators provided by linux to facilitate the use of commands and the processing of the results of command execution.

item.title: 27. Bash Shell - Text Processing: tr
item.description: We can use the tr command provided by linux to replace or remove text contents.

item.title: 26. Bash Shell - Text Processing: cut, paste, join
item.description: We can use the cut, paste, join commands provided by linux to retrieve, duplicate, or merge text file contents.

item.title: 25. Bash Shell - Text Processing: uniq, comm
item.description: We can use the uniq, comm command provided by linux to deduplicate, or compare text file contents.

item.title: 24. Bash Shell - Text Processing: wc, sort
item.description: We can use the wc, sort command provided by Linux to count the number of words, the number of bytes, and the sort of letters and numbers.

item.title: 23. Bash Shell - Text Processing: cat, tac, nl, head, tail
item.description: With word processing commands, we can easily get the text we want from a text output or text document.

item.title: 22. Bash Shell - Pattern Matching (Globbing Wildcards)
item.description: With the matching patterns, we can easily and efficiently find the files or directories we need.

item.title: 21. Pipelines - Use Other Commands' Running Results
item.description: With the pipe notation, we can pass the output of one program to the current as its initial data.

item.title: 20. Bash Shell - IO Redirection
item.description: With the IO redirection feature, we can easily manipulate the input and output of files or other information.

item.title: 19. Bash Shell - Command Prompt Settings Customization
13. Bourne and Bash Shells' Environment Variables
10. Alias - A Linux Command for Shortcut Creation
9. Text Editor - A Powerful Linux Text Editor's Basic Usage
